text:
<@U7SL518D6>, this is such a timely discussion. I was just using <https://blog.HubSpot.com/marketing/compress-image?hubs_signup-url=developers.HubSpot.com%2Fdocs%2Fcms%2Fguides%2Fspeed&hubs_signup-cta=null&_ga=2.165767486.1281838447.1598751878-1931719639.1595967195|this post> and Tinypng to compress my client's image files, but when I save the files from a new browser window they were in webp format. So I'd need to download, concert to png, before compressing. I noted that the file I was downloading (the webp file) was smaller than the finalized, compressed png, and was confused. This is such a helpful post for that reason.

So my big question to you is: let's say the original files are over 1 MB (my measuring stick for whether a file needs compression), with HS's automatic optimization of images, is the compression still helpful/necessary for SEO? Maybe minimally? Thanks for your thoughts.

All of the images on your site add up. If you are displaying images smaller than they will ever appear on the site. And larger than retina size. The extra file size slows the performance of your page for no good useful reason
